learning_outcomes.description: Demonstrate an awareness of the key historical and contemporary terms, concepts and debates which inform how we come to understand gender.
Understand how gender interacts with other social constructions and hierarchies (e.g. sexuality, race, ethnicity, class) in historical, contemporary, intercultural, local and global contexts.
Explore, analyse and reflect upon various social, political and cultural practices, texts and institutions as gendered and gendering.

Demonstrate an ability to use the critical methodologies of gender, feminist, sexuality and queer studies and scholarship to analyse how gender constructions shape the actual conditions of the individual and collective lives of ourselves and others.
Apply theory to practical experience for social transformation in relation to gender constructions and gender justice.

assessments.task_description:
The participation mark will be determined by considering a student’s overall participation in the tutorial series. The quality of a student’s contribution (not mere frequency of attendance) will be the main criteria.

To ensure you do well in tutorials you should always:

  • Do the readings.
  • Think about the broader implications of the topic in terms of theory and real-world applications.
  • Contribute to discussions meaningfully.
  • Engage respectfully with others.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

assessments.task_description:
Students will complete a short essay, responding to material given to them in class and made available on Blackboard. The short essay will be 500-800 words, and is worth 20% of your overall semester mark. Further advice about the short essay will be provided in class and on Blackboard.

The goal of this assessment is to demonstrate engagement with and understanding of basic gender history and ideas to help you integrate gender theory into your research essays.

Referencing Syle: Students may choose whichever referencing style they are comfortable with, as long as it remains consistent with the UQ Library style guide: https://guides.library.uq.edu.au/referencing.

Word Limits: A final word count that is within ±10% of the set length (500-800 words) is acceptable. Word count does not include any referencing or bibliography; however, discursive footnotes are included in the word count. A word count that is outside these 10% will receive a proportionate penalty and will be graded against the grading criteria.

AI: This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
You will write a research essay responding to one key topic, the details of which will be made available on Blackboard early in the semester. Essays should relate to the weekly lecture topics and the key concepts, themes, and theoretical perspectives from the course.

You may write using first person perspective in your essays and pay attention to the argument that you are making when answering the question. In your analysis of the question, make sure you engage with and reference the relevant course material including weekly readings from relevant theorists. Make sure your essay has a clear and logical structure and that your argument and analysis flows from your introduction to conclusion. Detailed marking criteria will be available on Blackboard and we will discuss the expectations around the research essay format in classes throughout the semester and in the Essay Writing Workshop. You should include at least 10 scholarly sources.

Referencing Syle: Students may choose whichever referencing style they are comfortable with, as long as it remains consistent with the UQ Library style guide: https://guides.library.uq.edu.au/referencing.

Word Limits: A final word count that is within ±10% of the set length (1200 words) is acceptable. Word count does not include any referencing or bibliography; however, discursive footnotes are included in the word count. A word count that is outside these 10% will receive a proportionate penalty and will be graded against the grading criteria.

AI: This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
More information about the exam will be discussed in the Week 13 Lecture. The purpose of the exam is to identify the knowledge you have acquired and your grasp of the broader themes from the course.

AI: This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 1: Why Gender Matters

In our first lecture, we will unpack the history of gender. What is it? How do we experience it day to day? How has our understanding of it changed over the years? What can be gained from studying gender and its impacts? There will also be a brief overview of the course, assessment, and expectations.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 1: Why Gender Matters In our first lecture, we will unpack the history of gender. What is it? How do we experience it day to day? How has our understanding of it changed over the years? What can be gained from studying gender and its impacts? There will also be a brief overview of the course, assessment, and expectations.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 2: Constructing Gender and the 'Other'

This week we will consider how gender has been both constructed and questioned throughout history, culminating in an engagement with theorists such as Simone de Beauvoir and Luce Irigaray. We will confront and unpack binary categories, such as woman/man, self/other, subject/object, homosexual/heterosexual and examine the social pressures behind their construction and use.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 2: Constructing Gender and the 'Other' This week we will consider how gender has been both constructed and questioned throughout history, culminating in an engagement with theorists such as Simone de Beauvoir and Luce Irigaray. We will confront and unpack binary categories, such as woman/man, self/other, subject/object, homosexual/heterosexual and examine the social pressures behind their construction and use.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 2: Constructing Gender and the 'Other'

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 2: Constructing Gender and the 'Other'

learning_activities.topic:
Week 3: Troubling Gender

In this lecture, we will think about the entangled relationships between how we perceive sex and gender in our own bodies, and the bodies of others, and how we can complicate or trouble these understandings. Butler's performativity theories will be brought into contact with more recent Queer Theory, to consider how queer and trans theorists have expanded on and further complicated these ideas.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 3: Troubling Gender In this lecture, we will think about the entangled relationships between how we perceive sex and gender in our own bodies, and the bodies of others, and how we can complicate or trouble these understandings. Butler's performativity theories will be brought into contact with more recent Queer Theory, to consider how queer and trans theorists have expanded on and further complicated these ideas.

learning_activities.topic_description: Week 3: Troubling Gender

learning_activities.topic:
Week 4: Race and Gender

In Week 4, we will look at the influence of race upon gender, and of gender upon race. Key theorists such as Audre Lorde, bell hooks, and Aileen Moreton-Robinson will guide our thinking on intersectionality to critique the hegemony of white feminism. We will discuss the ways that race, gender, and other identities produce entanglements that oppress or privilege particular bodies.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 4: Race and Gender In Week 4, we will look at the influence of race upon gender, and of gender upon race. Key theorists such as Audre Lorde, bell hooks, and Aileen Moreton-Robinson will guide our thinking on intersectionality to critique the hegemony of white feminism. We will discuss the ways that race, gender, and other identities produce entanglements that oppress or privilege particular bodies.

learning_activities.topic_description: Week 4: Race and Gender

learning_activities.topic:
Week 5: Labouring the Point: Gendered Work

In this lecture we will consider the ways in which social and cultural hierarchies of labour, work, and economies have impacts on gendered realities. We will examine issues such as the gendered wage gap, unpaid domestic labour, 'feminised' industries, and Tradwives. We will see the ways that the category of 'work' has profound implications for participation in society more broadly.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03

We will see the ways that the category of 'work' has profound implications for participation in society more broadly.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 6: Indigenous Perspectives

In this class we'll hear the crucial perspectives of First Nations women in relation to feminism and conceptualising gender, particularly the ways in which coloniality, whiteness and race intersect in complex ways with notions of gender in the past and in the present.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 6: Indigenous Perspectives In this class we'll hear the crucial perspectives of First Nations women in relation to feminism and conceptualising gender, particularly the ways in which coloniality, whiteness and race intersect in complex ways with notions of gender in the past and in the present.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 7: Boys will be Boys

This week we focus on recent trends and key questions in the field of masculinities. As well as presenting a summary of the key theories relating to masculinity studies, we will dispel common narratives supporting the idea that there is an oppositional relationship between masculinities and feminism, and contextualise the recent trends towards hyper-masculinity, and the pursuit of 'traditional' masculine values.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03

learning_activities.topic:
Week 8: Gendered Violence

This week we will examine our cultural and judicial understandings of sexual and gendered violence. This vital lecture will consider the role of gender in constructing victim/perpetrator narratives that ultimately impact upon the perceived validity of sexual assault and sexual violence. We unpack ideas around consent, and review theories designed to overcome the threat of sexual harms in Australian society.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03

We unpack ideas around consent, and review theories designed to overcome the threat of sexual harms in Australian society.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 9: Medical Bodies

In this lecture we will consider the ways in which social and cultural perceptions of gender may become dangerous, and even life-threatening. We will examine issues such as the gender bias in research and data, medical misogyny and transmisogyny, and reproductive rights. We will also examine how inequities in data and research entrench and reinforce negative gendered assumptions, socially, medically, and legally. Whose medical rights are privileged and who is denied these rights?

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03

learning_activities.topic:
Week 10: No Classes

No classes due to Labor Day Public Holiday.
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 10: No Classes No classes due to Labor Day Public Holiday.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 11: Gender and Popular Culture

Images, texts, and sounds via television, film, music, performances, magazines, comics, novels, games, fashion, and advertising all produce and represent a dominant set of beliefs and values about masculinity and femininity. In this lecture we explore the deep entanglement of gender and popular culture in the production and reproduction of gender norms and gendered subjects.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03

Week 11: Gender and Popular Culture

learning_activities.topic_description: Week 11: Gender and Popular Culture

learning_activities.topic:
Week 12: Disability, Gender & Sexuality

In this lecture we will consider the relationship between gender, ability, and disability. We will explore how experiences of disability are influenced by gender, sexuality, race, class, and age, and how this relates to medical and scientific hierarchies. We will think about how people with diverse gender identities experience disability, and what this can tell us about social constructions of bodies.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03

learning_activities.topic:
Week 13: Gendered Futures

In this lecture we reflect on the work of the past twelve weeks, and reassess our ideas of how we experience gender each day, and the way that gendered expectations and ideals inform our behaviour and outlook. As we look towards the future, how can we ensure gender experience and gender difference are adequately embraced and supported in our society? We approach the subject of gender justice, and imagine what a world without gendered norms could look like, and what steps we need to take to ensure a gender just world.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03

We approach the subject of gender justice, and imagine what a world without gendered norms could look like, and what steps we need to take to ensure a gender just world.
